title: Multiple issues on Checkout Process

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
#### Description
While reviewing the Shopify POS application we found that the application was encrypting the CHD information, but it was leaving the amount outside of the payload and the post lacked any sort of HMAC signature preventing replay attacks.  In addition, given the application does not enforce SSL Pinning a malicious seller could easily install a certificate to force messages through a proxy in which the attacker could alter content. 

**Disclosure: We used the cards provided on https://docs.shopify.com/manual/more/shopify-payments/testing-shopify-payments but all of them returned as rejected.  Because of this we are assuming that given both messages were declined both altered or unaltered the application is vulnerable. **

ISSUE 1)

ISSUE 2) The second issue sounds like These POST messages can be replayed. The transactions seams to lack an HMAC signature which a time constrain to reduce the window of opportunity for attacks.  We tested these request from different machines, and IPs and they still get a job assigned. 

#### Recommendations
For issue 1) include the amount on the encrypted payload to further protect the packet and also raise the for people trying to abuse the POS application. 
For issue 2) the use of an HMAC that adds the price, could also make sure the payload is not altered.

activities.message:
Even if we were to change our app in the ways you suggest, a malicious shop owner could still perform the same attacks in other ways, for instance by modifying the POS app to display incorrect information, or by creating a look-alike app. Shopify already has other mechanisms in place to detect and prevent fraudulent activity on the part of shop owners. Buyers can also submit chargebacks through their credit card company in the event that an incorrect amount has been charged by the shop owner.

Thank you for your interest in improving the security of the Shopify platform.

@clayton, even though your statement of "even if you change the app malicious shop owners can still perform other attacks" These specific attacks are the easiest to mitigate and most surely one of the easiest way of attacking the app externally (out of the ways you mentioned). 

Both of the other methods require either iOS development knowledge and/or reverse engineering and patching iOS. The latter being very complex compared to what I mentioned and they are out of your control. On the other hand, the issues mentioned on this report are something you can fix and take control, and it is still my recommendation that you should fix.
